title: 114_s2526
content: The Act titled "Made in America Manufacturing Communities Act of 2016" establishes a program to designate and support manufacturing communities. The Act establishes a program to improve US manufacturing competitiveness by designating and supporting manufacturing communities. The Secretary will establish the program and provide support to designated manufacturing communities. The Act establishes a program to improve US manufacturing competitiveness by designating and supporting manufacturing communities. Preferential consideration may be given to consortium members seeking financial or technical assistance if consistent with the economic development strategy. The program aims to enhance US manufacturing competitiveness by supporting designated manufacturing communities. Consortium members may receive priority for financial or technical assistance if they meet all requirements. Participating agencies include the Department of Agriculture, Commerce, Defense, Education, Energy, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Transportation, and the Appalachian Regional Commission. The participating agencies in the program include the Department of Labor, Transportation, Appalachian Regional Commission, Delta Regional Authority, Environmental Protection Agency, National Science Foundation, and Small Business Administration. Each agency must identify applicable programs for the established program. The participating agencies in the program include various government departments and organizations. A participating program is identified under specific criteria. When multiple members of the same consortium apply for financial or technical assistance, the agency head can determine preference allocation. The agency can determine preference allocation among consortium members applying for financial or technical assistance. Coordination may be required if multiple members are selected for preference. A report is due within 90 days of the date. The head of each participating agency must submit a report within 90 days detailing how preferential consideration will be given for financial or technical assistance. The Secretary may provide a Federal point of contact to help manufacturing community consortia access funds and assistance under the program. The head of a participating agency may award financial or technical assistance to a member of a consortium designated as a manufacturing community for the purpose of improving the competitiveness of US manufacturing. The recipient can use the assistance to support investments in an ecosystem. Investments supported under this program for improving US manufacturing competitiveness may include infrastructure, access to capital, promotion of exports, workforce training, energy efficiency, business incubators, site preparation, and advanced research. The Secretary of Commerce coordinates with participating agencies to identify programs for improving US manufacturing competitiveness, leveraging activities from non-Federal sources and avoiding duplication of efforts. Manufacturing communities are designated under this program. The Secretary designates manufacturing communities through a competitive process involving eligible consortiums representing regions with higher education and private sector entities. The Secretary designates manufacturing communities through a competitive process involving eligible consortiums representing regions with higher education, private sector, and government entities, along with private sector partners, economic development groups, financial institutions, and utilities. The lead applicant must be a district organization. The lead applicant for designating manufacturing communities must be a district organization, Indian tribe, consortium of Indian tribes, State, or political subdivision engaged in economic or infrastructure development activities. The lead applicant for designating manufacturing communities must be a district organization, Indian tribe, consortium of Indian tribes, State, or political subdivision, institution of higher education, or nonprofit organization acting in cooperation with officials of a political subdivision of a State. Regions can be defined by a consortium with approval from the Secretary. The consortium can define the region it represents, which must be large enough to contain key technologies and small enough for close collaboration. Designations are for 2 years and can be renewed upon application. The Secretary may renew a designation for an eligible consortium for 2 years upon application. The consortium can modify its composition or submit a revision to the plan or strategy. The Secretary evaluates eligible consortiums for renewal based on performance against previous designations and project-specific metrics proposed. The Secretary evaluates eligible consortiums for renewal based on project-specific metrics proposed in the consortium's application, potential changes to the consortium composition, and other relevant criteria. An eligible consortium seeking designation must submit an application to the Secretary with details on regional boundaries and manufacturing concentration. The eligible consortium must provide an assessment of its manufacturing concentration and local industrial ecosystem in its application for designation. This includes details on workforce, suppliers, research, infrastructure, and operational improvements. The eligible consortium must provide an evidence-based plan for developing components of the manufacturing ecosystem, including specific investments and operational improvements to make the region uniquely competitive. The consortium must provide an evidence-based plan for developing the manufacturing ecosystem, including investments and operational improvements to enhance competitiveness. The Secretary will evaluate applications based on outcome-based metrics, benchmarks, milestones, and other relevant factors. The Secretary evaluates applications based on regional cooperation and national manufacturing competitiveness. Previously recognized consortiums are deemed manufacturing communities. The Secretary may accept transferred funds from other agencies to support designated manufacturing communities.
